Nebraska Agricultural Statistics ISSUED COOPERATIVELY BY United States Department of Agriculture Dirision of Crop and Livestock Estimates AND Nebraska State Department of Agriculture Division of Agricultural Statistics h. j. Mclaughlin Secretary of Agriculture Compiled by A. E. ANDERSON, State and Federal Statistician F. K. REED, Asst. Statistician LINCOLN, NEBRASKA
BURR PUBLISHING COMPANY AURORA—LINCOLN CENTRAL CITY
H. J. Mclaughlin Secretary of Agriculture

9 To His Excellency: HON. ADAM McMULLEN, Governor of Nebraska. Sir: A further endeavor is made in this 1926 report of agricultural statistics to publish more complete and detailed records of Nebraska's outstanding industry, agriculture, and tu show much of it by graphical illustrations. The 'report also contains much new material that is of interest and value to agriculture. The demand for agricultural statistics has increased greatly. Farmers realize that sup - ply and demand are leading factors in price changes and they desire up-to-date information published in the current monthly reports, as well <ts ihe historical background furnished by the annual reports. There has been a keen demand for statistics from the marketing associ - ations and this will increase as cooperative marketing associations expand their activities. Crop statistics will be one of the first requisites in case a national marketing association is formed for handling agricultural commodities. Public schools and colleges are using the annual reports in teaching agriculture. Railroads and manufacturers are keenly interested in agricultural statistics and the value to them reflects oack to the interest of farmers in the way of furnishing adequate transportation and the economical distribution of manufactured com - modities. The 1926 crop production in general was far from being satisfactory. In fact, it was one of our poorest years from a crop production standpoint. About half of the counties had extremely light yields of all crops. Central Nebraska crops received the greatest injury from the drouth. Shortage of pasture, hay and feed forced the marketing of large numbers of cattle in central and southern Nebraska. The December 1 value of crops was $256,738,000 as compared to #310,180,000 in 1925 and #358,901,000 in 1924. The gross returns from livestock marketed in 1926 were the largest of the past seven years. This was brought about by the increase marketing of cattle and sheep, and the ad - vanced price of hogs. Supplies of cattle were depleted due to forced marketing and the marketing during 1927 will undoubtedly fall far below those of 1926. Prices of cattle and sheep average slightly less than in 1925 but prices of hogs averaged higher. The sales of major crops brought #74,111,294 as compared to #110,973,945 in 1925. Livestock brought #344,598,858 as compared to #326,470,130 in 1925. Total sales of crops «nd livestock were #418,710,152 as compared to #437,444,075 in 1925. This shows a marked recovery since 1921 the year of heaviest price deflation when total sales of crops and livestock were #257,059,301. Even with this increase in sales the farmer is not enjoying the prosperity that he had before the war as the index of prices of commodities the farmer buys is higher than the index of prices of commodities he sells which naturally gives him a lower purchasing power than in prewar days. The second year's work under the re-organized cooperation with the Federal Division of Crop and Livestock Estimates has progressed satisfactorily. The work in gathering agricultural statistics through the assessors has been developed and most of the deputy assessors have done satisfactory work. Much credit is due the assessors for furnishing the basic acreage information. Monthly reports in mimeograph form have been issued. Planting intentions reports are issued far enough in advance to enable farmers to adjust their acreage if it seems advisable. The pig surveys enable farmers to adjust the pig crops in accordance with demand. Reports are issued on cattle on feed, sheep on feed, fall marketings far enough in advance to be of value to feeders and breeders of livestock. A mid-month report based upon the re - ports of bankers is issued throughout the crop season. The Division of Agricultural Statis - tics receives wide publicity to its numerous articles on agriculture and averages from one to several news stories each week in the leading papers of the state. Crop and livestock reporting methods have recently been developed greatly. The so called percentage of judgment estimates have been eliminated and basic sample data is now being collected from representative samples of the whole. Records show that even very small samples give practically the same indications of changes in acreage that are shown by com - plete surveys. The crop meter which is an adaptation of the common speedometer is used for measuring acreage and gives very accurate results on major crops. Much basic information on livestock is collected and this together with a study of the assessment records of livestock makes a dependable basis for estimating livestock and the service as a whole is meeting the increasing demands satisfactory without material increase in expenditures. H. J. McLaughKn. Secretary of Agriculture.

GROSS CROP AND LIVESTOCK SALES, INDEX NUMBERS AND PURCHASING POWER The gross value of crops sold is based on the average price of 12 months and the estimated iiuantity shipped out of the county. It Includes all major crops. The gross value of livestock sold is based upon the absolute number sold each month and the average weight and value of the same for each month. The price index of agricultural products is the comparison of the average farm price of each year with the average farm price for the period, 1910-1914. inclu - sive. The relative farm purchasing power is determined by dividing the farm price index by the wholesale price index of non-agricultural products. 190 BASIS AND ACCURACY OF CROP AND LIVESTOCK REPORTS ACTUAL COTTON GINNINGS COMPARED WITH FEDERAL COTTON CROP ESTIMATES | Bureau's i Census ! Bureau's Estimate Over estimate or Ginnings i Estimate Per cent of under estimate Year i Bales* I Bal- s* I Ginnings ! % •Thousands of Bales. The Bureau of Census collects data on the ginnings of cotton each year. Com - parison of the total cotton ginned is made with the estimates of the Division of Crop and Livestock Estimates in the foregoing table. It will be noted that with few exceptions, the Division's estimates run very closely to the actual ginnings, and that the average error for the past 18 years is only 2.1% under the actual quantity. Cotton is a difficult crop to estimate and it may be assumed that the estimates of other crops are as close to the actual quantity produced as cotton, if not closer. There has been marked development recently in the methods of estimating crops. The old percentage method of estimating has been abandoned and actual sample acreage data that is representative of the whole is gathered In the individual farm surveys and the rural carriers' survey. The crop meter which is an adaptation of the common speedometer is being used to measure acreage and has proven to be very dependable for all major crops and for minor crops that are grown in concentrated areas. Methods of checking incompleteness in assessor's acreage reports have made that source one of the best in many states. A large quantity of basic data on livestock is now available and the methods of estimating livestock have been developed greatly during the past few years.
